newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia 10-yr bond continues record breaking run.
newsitem.headline: Australia 10-yr bond continues record breaking run.

text.p: *Long-dated Australian bond yields struck lower again on the Thursday as weak retail trade data spurred on an initial U.S.-led rally.
*Focus switches to barrage of U.S. data over next two days.

Long-dated Australian bond yields struck lower again on the Thursday as weak retail trade data spurred on an initial U.S. led rally and took the 10-year yield to its lowest level since the early 1970s.

Although it is early days yet, given that the Reserve Bank only lopped a 1/2 point off official rate to 5.0 percent on Wednesday, any more data like today's could stir up thoughts of another monetary policy easing.
June retail trade fell 1.8 percent and second quarter real trade fell 0.5 percent when median expectations had been for small rises in both cases.

"A dismal month for retailers to cap off a dismal quarter. These are not the sort of numbers that make retailers run out and hire new staff," said Craig James, senior economist at Colonial State Bank.

"If the RBA is treating the current cycle like past cycles, then it is making a mistake. The forces of job insecurity, redundancies and cost cutting are powerful and appear more than transitory," he added.
The 10-year bond futures contract hit a fresh record high of 93.675 on the data, overtaking the previous 93.640 peak last week, taking the 10-year yield below 6.35 percent at one stage.
However, Commonwealth Bank senior economist Michael Blythe believes that the impact of previous interest rates reductions are now following through.
"We suspect that today's data may represent the last gasp of that weak spending picture," Blythe added.
September and December bill futures continued to trade below the new cash rate with the latter touching 95.14 at one stage, equating to a cash rate of 4.86 percent.
The focus now switches to the U.S., which faces a barrage of data over the next two days. The next key local event is next week's labour force report for July next Thursday.
The U.S. market staged an impressive rally on Wednesday amid a broad brush of interest, but faces several tests, not least the July non-farm payrolls on Friday.
Later on Thursday the market sees the advanced second quarter GDP, the weekly jobless claims report and the Chicago Purchasing Management Index for for July.

The recent buoyancy of the U.S. is expected to remain a positive backdrop for the local debt, keeping expectations high for a further narrowing in spread margins. Although the market has yet to take out last week's 25 b.p. low on the 10-year spread to U.S., analysts still see parity as a possibility.
